official-title.#text:
To amend the Public Health Service Act to establish a program of research regarding the risks posed
			 by the presence of dioxin, synthetic fibers, chemical fragrances, and
			 other components of feminine hygiene products.

sponsor.#text: Mrs. Carolyn B. Maloney of New York

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

Feminine hygiene products are widely used by women in the United States today, but there is not
			 enough research on the components of these products.

Women may be exposed to substances in tampons and other menstrual products for as long as 60 years
			 over the course of their reproductive lives. The average woman may use as
			 many as 16,800 tampons in her lifetime. A woman on menopausal hormone
			 therapy may use as many as 24,360 tampons in her lifetime.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
International Agency for Research
			 on Cancer

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, have concluded that
			 dioxins are a probable human carcinogen (cancer-causing agent).

text.#text: Trace amounts of dioxins can be found in tampons or other feminine hygiene products. The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (referred to in this section as the

quote.#tail:
) has historically relied on data provided by manufacturers of feminine hygiene products in
			 determining product safety.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
currently requires tampon manufacturers to routinely monitor dioxin levels in raw
			 materials and finished tampons, this information is not readily available
			 to the public. The

should consider whether to expand regulation to
			 include other types of feminine hygiene products and a broader list of
			 contaminants.

is amended by adding
			 at the end the following section:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Part F of title IV of the Public Health Service Act

header.#text: Research on dioxin and other potentially harmful components of feminine hygiene products
Research on dioxin and other potentially harmful components of feminine hygiene products

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall provide for the
			 conduct or support of research to determine the extent to which the
			 presence of dioxins, synthetic fibers, chlorine, and other components,
			 including contaminants and substances used as fragrances, in tampons and
			 other feminine hygiene products—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of Research on Women’s Health

text.#text:
poses any risks to the health of women who use the products, including risks relating to cervical
			 cancer, endometriosis, infertility, ovarian cancer, breast cancer, immune
			 system deficiencies, pelvic inflammatory disease, toxic shock syndrome,
			 and bacterial and yeast infections; and

poses any risks to the health of children of women who used such products during or before the
			 pregnancies involved, including risks relating to fetal and childhood
			 development.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall include research to confirm the data on tampons and other
			 feminine hygiene products submitted to the

quote.#tail:
means tampons, pads, liners, cups, sponges, and similar products used by women with respect to
			 menstruation or other genital-tract secretions.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall be periodically submitted to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Administrator of the
			 Environmental Protection Agency

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
. Such reports shall be made available to the public
			 through the data system and clearinghouse program established under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Chairman of the Consumer Product
			 Safety Commission
